body_content.explanation: When you play, especially as a child, you spend time doing an enjoyable and/or entertaining activity:
examples: The children spent the afternoon playing with their new toys.
My daughter used to play with the kids next door.

body_content.explanation: to take part in a game or other organized activity:
examples: Do you want to play cards/football (with us)?
Irene won't be able to play in the tennis match on Saturday.
Which team do you play for?
Luke plays centre-forward (= plays in that position within the team).

body_content.explanation: to compete against a person or team in a game:
examples: Who are the Giants playing next week?

body_content.explanation: to hit or kick a ball in a game:
examples: He played the ball back to the goalkeeper.
A good pool player takes time deciding which shot to play.

body_content.explanation: (in a card game) to choose a card from the ones you are holding and put it down on the table:
examples: She played the ace of spades.

body_content.explanation: to perform an entertainment or a particular character in a play, film, etc.:
examples: Scottish Opera played to full houses every night.
I didn't realize that "Macbeth" was playing (= being performed) at the festival.
In the movie version, Branagh played the hero.

body_content.explanation: to behave or pretend in a particular way, especially in order to produce a particular effect or result:
examples: to play dead/dumb
Would you mind playing host (= entertaining the guests)?

body_content.explanation: to deceive someone to make them laugh or in order to get an advantage over them:
examples: She loves playing practical jokes on her friends.
When I saw the gun, my first thought was that he must be playing a joke.
He thought someone was trying to play a joke on him when he received the email.
One spring, his students played a trick on him by hiding his books.
Sometimes our nervous system can play nasty tricks on the body.

body_content.explanation: to help to achieve something:
examples: My thanks to everyone who has played a part in saving the hospital.
Better sanitation helped to eradicate malaria, but DDT also played a part.
The government wants us all to play a part in fighting terrorism.
Some of the people who will play a part in rebuilding the country are returning there for the first time in decades.

body_content.explanation: to perform music on an instrument or instruments:
examples: He learned to play the clarinet at the age of ten.
Play us a song!/Play a song for us!
On Radio London they play African and South American music as well as rock and pop.
They could hear a jazz band playing in the distance.

body_content.explanation: to (cause a machine to) produce sound or a picture:
examples: Play the last few minutes of the video again.

body_content.explanation: to direct or be directed over or onto something:
examples: Firefighters played their hoses onto the base of the fire.
A fountain was playing (= sending out water) in the courtyard outside.

body_content.explanation: (of something you see, such as light) to move quickly or be seen for a short time:
examples: A smile played across/over/on his lips.

body_content.explanation: to risk money, especially on the results of races or business deals, hoping to win more money:
examples: He plays the horses/the stock market.

body_content.explanation: a piece of writing that is intended to be acted in a theatre or on radio or television:
examples: a radio play
"Did you see the play (= the performance of the play) on Thursday?" "No, I went on Wednesday night."

body_content.explanation: the activity of taking part in a sport or a game:
examples: Rain stopped play during the final of the National Tennis Championship.

body_content.explanation: a plan or a small set of actions in a sport:
examples: The new pitcher made a great play on that throw to first base.

body_content.explanation: If a ball is in play, it is in a position where it can be hit, kicked, or thrown:
examples: She managed to keep the ball in play.
The referee let the game carry on as the ball was in play.
The match was very broken, with the ball in play for a total of only 41 minutes.

body_content.explanation: If a ball is out of play, it is not in a position where it can be hit, kicked, or thrown:
examples: The ball had gone out of play.
In tennis, the ball is out of play if it goes outside the lines or bounces more than once.

body_content.explanation: activity that is not serious but done for enjoyment, especially when children enjoy themselves with toys and games:
examples: The kids don't get much time for play in the evenings.
We watched the children at play in the park.

body_content.explanation: movement:
examples: the play of moonlight across the water
the play of emotion across/on his face

body_content.explanation: the fact that a rope or a structure is free to move, especially a small distance:
examples: Aircraft wings are designed to have a certain amount of play in them.
